Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Polyethylene Glycol-Coated Patch Versus Axillary Drainage in Breast Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: women aged ≥18 years with breast cancer scheduled for axillary lymph node dissection were randomly assigned (1:1)

Participants.evidence: women aged ≥18 years with breast cancer scheduled for axillary lymph node dissection

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned (1:1) to receive either a polyethylene glycol-coated patch or axillary drainage

Objective.evidence: This multicentre randomised controlled trial evaluated the clinical outcomes and direct costs

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were the need for an emergency department visit and the incidence of seroma, assessed over the postoperative period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 227 patients were randomised, with 115 in the patch group and 112 in the drainage group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on all participants using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of emergency department visits was significantly higher in the drainage group (33.0%) compared to the patch group (7.0%), with an incidence rate difference of 26.1% (95% CI 14.5 to 37.7; p < 0.0001).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported in either group.
